meta.name: dc.title

meta.content: 2016 The Minerals, Metals & Materials Society
meta.name: dc.copyright

meta.content: In the present study, surface texture features and chemical properties of two types of cokes, made from coal tar by either 1-stage heat treatment or 2-stage heat treatment, were researched. The relationship between surface texture characteristics and the chemical properties was identified through molecular weight distribution, insolubility of coal tar, weight loss with temperature increase, coking yield, and polarized light microscope analysis. Rapidly cleared anisotropy texture in cokes was observed in accordance with the coking temperature rise. Quinoline insolubility and toluene insolubility of coal tar increased with a corresponding increases in coking temperature. In particular, the cokes produced by the 2-stage heat treatment (2S-C) showed surface structure of needle cokes at a temperature approximately 50°C lower than the 1-stage heat treatment (1S-C). Additionally, the coking yield of 2S-C increased by approximately 14% in comparison with 1S-C.

meta.content: Effects of Two-stage Heat Treatment on Delayed Coke and Study of Their Surface Texture Characteristics - JOM

In the present study, surface texture features and chemical properties of two types of cokes, made from coal tar by either 1-stage heat treatment or 2-stage heat treatment, were researched. The relationship between surface texture characteristics and the chemical properties was identified through molecular weight distribution, insolubility of coal tar, weight loss with temperature increase, coking yield, and polarized light microscope analysis. Rapidly cleared anisotropy texture in cokes was observed in accordance with the coking temperature rise. Quinoline insolubility and toluene insolubility of coal tar increased with a corresponding increases in coking temperature. In particular, the cokes produced by the 2-stage heat treatment (2S-C) showed surface structure of needle cokes at a temperature approximately 50°C lower than the 1-stage heat treatment (1S-C). Additionally, the coking yield of 2S-C increased by approximately 14% in comparison with 1S-C.

head.title: Effects of Two-stage Heat Treatment on Delayed Coke and Study of Their Surface Texture Characteristics | SpringerLink

div.div: Effects of Two-stage Heat Treatment on Delayed Coke and Study of Their Surface Texture Characteristics

header.h1: Effects of Two-stage Heat Treatment on Delayed Coke and Study of Their Surface Texture Characteristics
header.p:
JOM
volume
69
,
pages
2460–2466 (
2017
)
Cite this article

li.p:
437
Accesses

3
Citations

div.p: In the present study, surface texture features and chemical properties of two types of cokes, made from coal tar by either 1-stage heat treatment or 2-stage heat treatment, were researched. The relationship between surface texture characteristics and the chemical properties was identified through molecular weight distribution, insolubility of coal tar, weight loss with temperature increase, coking yield, and polarized light microscope analysis. Rapidly cleared anisotropy texture in cokes was observed in accordance with the coking temperature rise. Quinoline insolubility and toluene insolubility of coal tar increased with a corresponding increases in coking temperature. In particular, the cokes produced by the 2-stage heat treatment (2S-C) showed surface structure of needle cokes at a temperature approximately 50°C lower than the 1-stage heat treatment (1S-C). Additionally, the coking yield of 2S-C increased by approximately 14% in comparison with 1S-C.

As a raw material of artificial graphite, cokes are prepared by coal tar. In Korea, over 1 million tons of coal tar is produced a year. Coal-based cokes have been used industrially as an outstanding carbon material in semiconductors, light-emitting diodes, solar cells, supercapacitors used in the vehicle batteries and negative electrode material for secondary batteries. Currently, Korea has to import raw materials for artificial graphite due to a lack of source technology.
1
–
3

Cokes for carbon material are generally produced by a polycondensation reaction and removal of volatile components while heated at 400–600°C.
4
–
6
Additionally, cokes can be divided into anisotropic and isotropic cokes according to surface texture. Needle cokes, which typically have an anisotropic surface texture, are used as the main electrode material in ultra-high-power electric arc furnaces with low coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE).
7
,
8
This particular type of electrode has a low modulus of elasticity, high thermal conductivity and low CTE.
2
,
9
Furthermore, cokes with isotropic characteristics can be used as bearings and other mechanical carbon materials due to factors such as highly mechanical properties, excellent friction stability and dense structure texture.
10

The preferred manufacturing method for artificial graphite is a complex process that requires the product, which is formed by the mixture of the cokes and a binder, to densify. The process first mixes the cokes with the binder, followed by calcination, and then the impregnation and calcination are repeated.

Specifically, during the calcination process, which increases the fine porosity and degasses volatile material, the mechanical properties of the carbon material are significantly weakened.
11
These issues are addressed by two means: repeating the impregnation and calcination as much as possible; or slowing down the rate of the temperature rise in calcination. However, these solutions add further disadvantages, which are time-consuming and expensive.
12
,
13

Production methods have attempted to shorten the manufacturing lead time by strengthening the self-sintering property without a binder, utilizing the modified pitch and employing mesocarbon microbeads (MCMB).
14
–
16

In this study, two types of cokes were manufactured by a 1-stage heat treatment and a 2-stage heat treatment, respectively. The change of surface texture features and chemical properties were analyzed, as well as the correlation of the two types of cokes were investigated.

The coal tar was produced in the iron-smelting process (POSCO Chem.tec, Korea) and used as the raw material for making needle cokes. The coal tar was purified by tetrahydrofuran (THF) at the beginning of the coking process. The refined coal tar (RCT) contains carbon (91.77%), hydrogen (5.74%), nitrogen (1.75%), sulfur (0.64%), and oxygen (0.1%, by difference). The properties of the raw materials were characterized as Quinoline Insolubility (QI), Tetrahydrofuran Insolubility (THFI), Toluene Insolubility (TI), Benzene Insolubility (BI), Hexane Insolubility (HI), and β-resin as shown in Table
I
.

figcaption.b: Table I Characteristics of the raw materials

div.p:
The 1-stage heat treatment, known as the simple delayed coking process, is a coking method used world-wide as summarized in Fig.
1
. The cokes of the 1-stage heat treatment (1S-C) were manufactured from RCT by utilizing a vertical furnace, shown in Fig.
2
a. Specifications for 1S-C are as follows: RCT 50 g/sample; heating rate 10°C/min; N
2
purging rate 40 ml/min; stirring speed 70 rpm; heat treatment temperature 400–500°C; and reaction time 1–3 h.

Reprinted with permission from Ref.
4
Schematic diagram for the preparation of 1S-C and 2S-C.

In the 2-stage heat treatment (2S-C; or pressured-delayed coking process), the cokes were produced from RCT by using the 2S-C device shown in Fig.
2
b. This method has two steps: in the first step, the pressured coking process (PCP) was utilized to enhanced the molecular weight of the coal tar (2S-CT). In the second step, the delayed coking process (DCP) was used to manufacture 2S-C in the same manner as in 1S-C. Specifications for 2S-CT are as follows: 90 g/sample; heating rate 10°C/min; stirring speed 60 rpm; and pressure 10–15 kgf/cm
2
. Then, complete sealing of the reactor was checked by keeping a constant pressure at 10–15 kgf/cm
2
. Next, 2S-C was manufactured from 2S-CT using the following conditions: 2S-CT 50 g/sample; heating rate 10°C/min; N
2
purging rate 40 ml/min; stirring speed 70 rpm; heat treatment temperature 450–500°C; and reaction time 1-3 h.

The composition of the coal tar was determined using the Elemental Analysis (EA; TruSpec, LECO, USA). QI was examined in compliance with ISO 6791
17
and TI was measured in accordance with ISO 6376.
18
The variation in the molecular weight according to the pressured coking process was investigated by Matrix Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization–Time of Flight–Mass Spectrometer (MALDI–TOF–MS; Bruker Autoflex Speed TOF/TOF; Bruker, USA). The thermal characteristics were analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; STA 409 PC; Netzsch, Germany) from 20°C to 900°C at a heating rate of 5°C/min under nitrogen flow. Structural properties of cokes were evaluated by polarized light microscopy (BX51M; Olympus, Japan).

Figure
3
a summarizes the insolubility analysis of QI and TI in relation to temperature for 3 h in PCP. Figure
3
b presents the change of QI and TI in accordance with the reaction time of PCP at 330°C. PCP resulted in an approximate 0.5% QI increase in small quantities, whereas, the TI increase was approximately 6.77% larger than QI. Figure
3
shows that the insolubility increased proportionally with increasing reaction time and temperature. Thus, as shown in Fig.
4
, the β-resin of 2S-CT was gradually increased by 13%. Figures
3
and
4
show that PCP results in an increase in the molecular weight distribution degree especially of TI for 2S-CT. So, 2S-CT having increased average molecular weights without QI can form the mesophase more easily then RCT during the delayed coking process. Since a large amount of β-resin can make a high self-binding capacity,
19
the carbon blocks manufactured from 2S-CT can be produced without the use of binders.
Insolubility analyses of 2S-CT with temperature and time: (a) according to temperature at 3 h in PCP; (b) with reaction time at 330°C in PCP
2S-CT changes of β-resin depending on reaction time at PCP

Figure
5
illustrates the molecular weight distributions of 2S-CT and RCT via MALDI-TOF–MS. The
x
-axis indicates the molecular weight of a cation, and the
y
-axis is the measured intensity.
20
,
21
RCT exhibits molecular weight distributions from 170 to 450. 2S-CT, which was heated at 300°C for 3 h, has observed molecular weight distributions from 170 to 650; the remainder are 170–700. By increasing the temperature from 300°C to 360°C, the average molecular weights of RCT and 2S-CT were also changed to 310, 371, 400, 401, respectively.
22
,
23
According to these results, it is assumed that the average molecular weights of 2S-CT show a slight difference when changing the temperature from 330°C to 360°C. The change in the average molecular weights is possibly due to polycondensation and a sudden rise in cracking.
11
MALDI-TOF mass spectra (reflector mode) of the RCT, 2S-CT acquired using α-cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid as the matrix

It is clear from the TGA analysis that Fig.
6
d–f exhibits lower weight loss of volatile component compared to the others (Fig.
6
a–c). Therefore, it can be assumed that the 1S-C, which controlled the volatile matter by less than approximately 15% at 900°C, will not be swollen in the carbonization process.
24
Figure
7
shows the variations of volatile matter for 1S-C and 2S-C in relation to the temperature of PCP. The volatile matter of 2S-C decreased more than 0.7% in comparison to 1S-C. Additionally, in accordance with the PCP temperature increase, the volatile matter of 2S-C decreased. However, the volatile matter shown in Fig.
7
d, which was heat-treated at PCP of 360°C, increased approximately 2.1% more than shown in Fig.
7
c, which was heat-treated at PCP and 330°C. This observation implies that the high molecular weight 2S-CT was sharply cracked And that 1S-C weight gradually reduced from 200°C to 500°C more than the 2S-C weight. Therefore, 2S-C, having higher fixed carbon than 1S-C, can form the carbon block without swelling after carbonization.
TGA-curves of 1S-C with time and temperatures at 1-stage heat treatment in nitrogen: (a) 400°C-1 h; (b) 400°C-3 h; (c) 450°C-1 h; (d) 450°C-3 h; (e) 500°C-1 h; (f) 500°C-3 h
Comparison of 1S-C and 2S-C through TGA-curves in nitrogen: (a) 1S-C, 500°C-1 h; (b) 2S-C, PCP 300°C-3 h, DPC 500°C-1 h; (c) 2S-C, PCP 330°C-3 h, DPC 500°C-1 h; (d) 2S-C, PCP 360°C-3 h, DPC 500°C-1 h

Figure
8
depicts the polarized light microscopic analysis for 1S-C. Figure
8
a and b shows the isotropic texture, evidenced by the presence of a small spherical mesophase.
12
Depending on the increase of temperature and reaction time in IS-C, a remarkable anisotropic texture is formed, as shown in Fig.
8
c–i. In particular, when the experimental conditions of IS-C are 500°C for 2–3 h, needle cokes are clearly exhibited, as indicated in Fig.
8
h and i.
7
,
9
Likewise, Fig.
9
presents the polarized light microscopic analysis for 2S-C which is manufactured according to conditions of PCP and DCP. Thus, Figs.
8
and
9
show that the surface texture features of 1S-C and 2S-C can demonstrate the effect of 2S-C. The anisotropy was similarly observed in both the surface structures for Figs.
8
c–i and
9
a–i. Furthermore, the needle structure observed in Figs.
8
i and
9
g are nearly identical. In this regard, it can be observed that the surface texture features of needle cokes is manifested in 2S-C at a temperature approximately 50°C lower than in 1S-C. Therefore, the results of the polarization microscopy analysis show that PCP, which is treated at 360°C, readily causes the needle structure.

Polarized light microscope analysis images of 1S-C with temperature and time: (a) 400°C-1 h; (b) 400°C-2 h; (c) 400°C-3 h; (d) 450°C-1 h; (e) 450°C-2 h; (f) 450°C-3 h; (g) 500°C-1 h; (h) 500°C-2 h; (i) 500°C-3 h

Polarized light microscope analysis images of 2S-C: (a) PCP 300°C-1 h, DCP 450°C-1 h; (b) PCP 300°C-1 h, DCP 450°C-2 h; (c) PCP 300°C-1 h, DCP 500°C-1 h; (d) PCP 330°C-1 h, DCP 450°C-1 h; (e) PCP 330°C-1 h, DCP 450°C-2 h; (f) PCP 330°C-1 h, DCP 500°C-1 h; (g) PCP 360°C-1 h, DCP 450°C-1 h; (h) PCP 360°C-1 h, DCP 450°C-2 h; (i) PCP 360°C-1 h, DCP 500°C-1 h

Figure
9
shows the change of the coking yield according to temperature in PCP. The coking yield for 2S-C is increased by 14% more than in 1S-C. However, when 2S-C treated at 360°C in PCP was pyrolyzed, the coking yield decreased less than other 2S-Cs. From these results, it can be observed that the volatile matter of 2S-CT increases due to decomposition of the molecular structure, which has a very high molecular weight at 360°C in PCP.

There are two correlation trends between surface texture features and molecular weight. First, the molecular weight of 2S-CT, which can easily form into a needle structure, increased. Second, as shown in Figs.
5
,
7
, and
10
, the molecules of 2S-CT, which have a very high molecular weight, were decomposed. As mentioned above, the correlation of surface texture features with chemical properties indicates that the appropriate control on the coal tar molecular weight is essential to form the needle structure without difficulty.
5
,
7
In particular, the conditions that cause cracking and polycondensation at 360°C in PCP are suitable for needle cokes.
Change of coking yield with 2-stage heat treatment conditions
Four conclusions can be drawn according to the aforementioned results.

Firstly, though the coking process is developed from the 1-stage heat treatment to the 2-stage heat treatment, QI increased less than TI. Therefore, the amount of β-resin increased gradually depending on the temperature increase of the 2-stage heat treatment. Secondly, the molecular weight of 2S-CT increased according to increases of reaction time and temperature in PCP. Meanwhile, PCP at 360°C made the high molecular weight rapidly crack. Thirdly, the surface texture of needle cokes in 2S-C was produced at a temperature approximately 50°C lower than in 1S-C. Consequently, PCP at 360°C can readily form the needle structure. Finally, the coking yield increased up to 14% by converting the manufacturing method from 1S-C into 2S-C. The coking yield of 2S-C, which was treated at 360°C in PCP, increased less than other 2S-Cs because the very high molecular weight was decomposed.
